Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I gained confidence in my lab skills and learned about lab safety.
I learned how to do NMR and use SciFinder. I also got a lot better at EPs and Post Labs. Everything else was stuff covered last semester for the most part.
Lots of HNMR, surprisingly.
I learned a lot of reactions and lab techniques (mostly a continuation of last semester).
I learned a lot of laboratory skills for chemical synthesis, and I also learned a lot of lab safety skills. I also learned how to think critically and determine product purity.
I learned about various techniques for the synthesis and characterization of organic compounds. Also how to prepare for experimentation by understanding the hazards involved with each experiment.

Became relatively familiar with many synthetic techniques in organic chemistry such as reflux, vacuum filtration, recrystallization, etc. Also learned how to interpret NMR and use online chem databases. Pretty cool being able to actually perform reactions that we learn about in lecture.
I learned skills related to the synthesis of organic compounds, as well as their characterization.
Many organic chemistry skills and how each step we do is important in making our product
You'll learn general lab techniques. With a helpful TF it might even be enjoyable.
different experimental methods for synthesis and purification of organic compounds
organic synthesis
This lab course gave me insight as to what work in organic chemistry looks like.  It was definitely more engaging than first semester lab as well.
I learned several new laboratory techniques.
lab skills, troubleshooting in lab, began to enjoy synthesis experiments rather than stress about them
This course was basically a continuation of the organic chemistry laboratory skills that we learned in the first semester with the addition of a few new skills.

I perfected the lab skills from last semester. It was amazing that everything was kind of second nature, and it gave us more room to focus on learning more of the chemistry behind each experiment rather than the technique. I learned about different reactions and how to read and interpret NMR spectra. I learned how to make tylenol.
I further developed my lab skills, including safe practice, specific synthetic methods, and general organic chemistry knowledge such as mechanisms
I'm more familiar with basic orgo lab techniques, and I can more efficiently follow chemical protocols.
General Ochem lab.  Relatively fun, and learned applications from the O chem lectures.
I learned a lot of synthesis techniques.
How to synthesize things in organic chemistry.
I developed the ability to use laboratory techniques correctly and efficiently. I also learned how to properly compose professional-level lap reports in the field of chemistry.
I learned how to perform organic syntheses and how to analyze and characterize my results.
Lab skills. How to do lab things, but this semester is mostly focused on synthesis labs that require the skills for synthesis and analysis from the last labs.
Intermediate level organic chemistry lab techniques.
Analytical and research skills improved.
I learned how to conduct and design experiments related to chemical synthesis, isolation, and characterization.
Learned general organic chemistry lab skills: bench techniques, NMR and I analysis, etc.
Continuation of lab skills from 222L, ability to use SciFinder, interpretation of NMR
I learned about different chemical reactions and their mechanisms. I also learned about the concept of green chemistry and how simple it was to implement it in our lab.
how to do ochem labs
Chemical synthesis techniques. Theory behind organic chemistry synthesis and characterization (NMR, IR, TLC, etc.). Lab report preparation.
Reflux, TLC, IR, NMR, reading and writing scientific literature!
I learned some new laboratory techniques like taking melting point and infrared spectroscopy.

I built upon basic laboratory skills learned in the first semester of organic chemistry lab, including safety considerations, several common techniques, and the production of organized and professional lab notes and reports, as well as new useful skills such as analysis of HNMR spectra and the use of SciFinder to find reliable chemical information and articles.
223L taught us many important chemistry lab techniques, including IR spectroscopy, reflux, and NMR analysis.

More techniques in organic chemistry lab. Thinking about the effects of small changes in an experimental procedure on the yield and purity of a product. Recognizing the importance of all steps of a procedure and why certain things are done certain ways.
This course is a continuation of Orgo 1, with basically only NMR added on. You do get a lot of practice with reflux, synthesis and IR.
I mastered advanced organic chemistry synthesis techniques, including recrystalization, reflux, filtration, and others that were first taught in CHEM222L.

I learned the techniques (reflux, recrystallization, filtration, etc.) to synthesize an array of different organic compounds. I learned the chemistry behind the reactions we performed, and the safety procedures for lab work.
I developed a variety of useful lab skills and a clearer understanding of chemistry through this class.

Different chemical reactions and how they are actually carried out in lab.
Reinforcement of laboratory safety procedures
Furthering of lab organic chemistry synthesis, use of online database through casfinder, important techniques
Learned how to synthesize basic molecules including tylenol. I tried it and it was probably contaminated with some other chemical because I almost died,  so I guess it was cool.

Learned how to utilize a string of different organic chemistry techniques from first semester orgo lab in order to synthesize various compounds. Got really familiar with analyzing IR and NMR spectra. Polished science writing skills through compilation of the two major "post-lab" assignments.
I learned how to do a lot of the experiments we were learning in class like esterification, Diels Alder, etc.
My knowledge of basic chemical reactions and lab procedures was developed taking this course.
I was able to get adequate practice and become very comfortable with techniques that I learned last semester in o-chem lab 1 along with a few new interesting techniques such as NMR.

Reinforced skills from Orgo lab I: Reflux, separation by extraction, vacuum filtration, thin-layer chromatography, IR spectroscopy
New skills: How to use SciFinder, reading NMR spectra
Able to see reactions learned in class turn into a reality.
I gained the ability to connect what I was learning in lecture to experiments.
I developed new lab technique skills relevant to organic chemistry.

now that basic lab techniques have been taught, this half of the lab course focuses on a variety of synthesis reactions. many involve creating useful compounds like acetaminophen and salicylic acid, and cool ones that are colorful (and excitingly dangerous)!
basic lab skills, research skills, writing scientifically
I now know many different experimental methods for synthesizing organic compounds.

This course provided a practical way of understanding how some of the organic reactions we learn about in lecture are carried out in lab. Many of the laboratory skills that were emphasized are the same as in the first semester of lab, but this course has perhaps a greater emphasis on interpreting data from TLC, IR, and NMR.
I learned how to synthesize different products through reflux and how to characterize the products using skills like IR spectroscopy, NMR, and TLC.
I learned a lot about performing basic organic chemistry lab techniques
Lots of lab skills

Lots of lab chemistry skills were developed well, felt very confident in lab after taking this course
Really liked it
Learned techniques needed for synthesis of organic compounds

I developed an understanding of the driving physical forces behind chemical reactions. I also became familiarized with a number of recently discovered reactions involving interesting catalysts that are used extensively in a variety of industries. Leaning how to purify compounds and then analyze the final product was another skill that I developed.
I definitely earned a deeper level of understanding of organic chemistry, performing experiments based off the reactions I learned in Orgo Lecture.
I learned about various techniques and reactions in the organic chemistry lab.
Syntheses: aldol condensation, fischer esterification, FC acylation, etc.
Further developed my organic chemistry laboratory techniques.
The lab is teaches critical laboratory skills needed for any future chemist.
I learned a lot about actual lab techniques for organic chemists. This class compliments the lecture course well in that it reenforces reactions and mechanisms that we learn in the lecture.
how to conduct basic organic chemistry experiments in the lab, also spectroscopy
Basic lab skills
I learned laboratory techniques, along with analytical techniques.
I learned to apply the techniques learned in the first half of this class to perform syntheses.

I learned many lab skills through this course. This course was way more independent than general chemistry lab, so I was able to put many of my lab skills to good use while performing experiments. It was actually fun to be in the lab and carry out whole reactions by myself.
Further organic lab skills
Gained skill in various techniques needed for organic chemistry lab, particular syntheses and lab notes.
Lots of experimental procedures.
I gained laboratory skills and greatly increased my comfort level in a laboratory environment.
lab skills
This course built on last semester's techniques. The only new thing was learning how to read NMR.
Thorough understanding of organic chemistry lab techniques and proper lab etiquette.
confidence in all basic organic chemistry lab techniques and substances
Applied organic chemistry in lab and learned how to perform lab techniques safely

Knowledge: reinforce reactions, mechanisms, and concepts from orgo I and II
Skills: refine laboratory techniques learned in orgo lab I and NMR practice
I was able to improve upon the laboratory skills and techniques taught in 222L, and apply them in real experiments. Furthermore, we were able to learn about more laboratory equipment.
I continued to develop familiarity with common lab skills and analytical techniques.

This course was a wonderful introduction to many useful and relevant laboratory methods such as IR spectroscopy, TLC, recrystallization, melthin pont analysis, and reflux reactions. The experiments were interesting and generally useful in helping teach the material that was also covered in Chem 221.
Basic lab techniques
Developed a well-structured approach in applying the scientific method to chemistry. Engaged problem-solving skills in troubleshooting and solving issues during experiments.
How to work safely in a chemistry laboratory and how to assess and understand chemical literature.
I broadened my skills in the organic chemistry lab and learned more concepts relating to organic chemistry.

We got a chance to practice a variety of techniques repeatedly, which helped me become much more confident in the lab than I had previously been. For the first time, I got several really great yields for experiments.
I received a solid foundation in organic chemistry lab skills and more advanced reaction mechanisms.
Great lab skills.
Basic orgo lab skills, synthesis, analysis techniques.

Organic Chemistry Lab for the second semester is a phenomenal experience. I learned so much - methods for synthesis, purification, collection of product.  Techniques covered in the syllabus include heating at reflux, recrystallization, distillation, vacuum filtration, and column chromotography. We also do a comprehensive slate of evaluative procedures for most labs; for example, IR spectroscopy, thin layer chromotography, melt point analysis. I've learned more from this lab than I have from some of my full-credit classes.

Strengths: That it builds on skills from last semester.
Weaknesses: Towards the end of the semester, some of the labs seem repetitive in the types of skills we use to complete them.
Have a practice exam before lab practical

I wished that we could have done actual NMR to become more familiar with it. I liked how chill it was. The grading was harsh and nitpicky but I think that was just my TA. Professor DiMeglio is very kind, welcoming, and receptive to questions. The material is easy to understand when integrated with lecture materials and it is very easy to do well in this course.

At times it is very difficult to understand why you are losing points on assignments.  Rubrics effectively do not exist, since the standard is "correct/perfect content, professionally presented," which translates to "we can take off an unlimited amount of points for whatever we want."  Of course, if you get a kind TA you can get feedback and good scores, but if your TA gives above-average scores, you will be curved down at the end of the semester.  The only redeeming aspect is that the lab practical is multiple choice.  For context: I had great TAs both semesters, but I would still not recommend the course.  It is just not set up in a way that students can understand exactly what is expected of them.  Do not take this class if it is not required.
HNMR was not as emphasized as a required skill as I would have liked, but otherwise everything was cool.

Strengths: The lab is not stressful every week and the workload is definitely manageable. Dr. D is also very helpful and loves to answer questions! Also you're not graded on yield, which is good, because sometimes yield would be super low.
Weakness: A lot of time spent in lab was not necessarily for the reaction itself, but rather for product characterization (always TLC, mp, IR) which actually takes a while to do each time. Although useful for analysis on post lab assignments, it seemed a bit redundant to do it every week for labs that we didn't turn in.

Strengths: This course kept me very engaged, and it also taught me a lot of lab safety skills and chemical synthesis skills. This course also helped me become a better scientific writer, especially with regards to lab notes and writing scientific reports.
 
Weaknesses: I cannot think of any!
A strength of the course is definitely the amount of hands on experience each student gets by working individually on each experiment.

Course was overall well structured and experiments generally worked. Some reactions involved pretty long refluxes though, but the timing was pretty well thought out so that there wasn't too much waiting time.
So much busy-work.

The TAs and Dr. DiMeglio were always very helpful throughout the labs. We learned a lot of techniques related to synthesis and characterization. We also learned mechanisms of reactions that related to what we were learning in organic chemistry class.

Strengths: TAs, the instructor, and the environment of the lab! It is very friendly and allows you to be relaxed during your experiments and not be afraid of making mistakes and telling them to the instructors. 
Weaknesses: The rubrics for some of the assignments
As is often the case with lab courses, the grading is fairly whack. While the grades are curved based on TF's, the entire process is still very unclear.

one weakness is that we kind of did the same thing every week (synthesis of some compound and then maybe purification and then characterization). also the material in lab didn't line up with material in lecture, so that was somewhat annoying.

seemed like we did reflux every week. It was applicable with what we were learning reaction-wise in class but I'd rather learn different lab techniques. also sometimes the requirements for what was needed in lab notes or on different assignments was unclear or inconsistent. i appreciate that the only major work from week to week was EPs since the course is only a half credit despite being more class time than any other course
This course is graded harshly, but the work is definitely manageable.
This course could be improved by allowing students to experiment more instead of giving them strict procedures.

The labs were well designed and the assignments were clear. Dr. Dimeglio was always readily available and approachable and made a real effort to get to know all of us, which I really appreciated. Grading could have been made a little clearer - it always felt like with the post-lab assignments that grading was somewhat arbitrary (sometimes I would lose points for things, othertimes I wouldn't) and it would have been helpful to have a clearer rubric rather than guessing what we had to include in order to get points. I think NMR lecture should be done by Dr. DiMeglio in a large pre-lab lecture, such as is typical in gen chem. I think I started off with a poor understanding, which really came around to haunt me by the time the final came around.

I liked that we got hands on experience and weren't graded on yield or purity, but were just expected to put in our best effort. I didn't love how the post lab assignments were graded - I felt like I was always losing points for not putting down something that the question didn't ask for.
The strength of this course is Professor Dimeglio.

This course is pretty straightforward. I do have an issue with the subjectivity of the grading for a lot of the assignments. Many times grades fluctuated greatly depending on the TF that you were assigned to. This seemed to be unfair to those who had a harsher grader versus those who had a more lenient grader.

It is what it is. I think the experiments are good at showing us the applicability of organic chemistry in real life. For example, I really enjoyed the dilantin and the tylenol synthesis because they showed us that organic chemistry helps people in their daily life. Of course there are weaknesses that everybody will complain about like inconsistent grading and long lab hours etc, but it just is what it is and you likely just have to take it. One really bad weakness though, is that the instructions on the post lab assignments look deceivingly clear. Things are outlined in the guide to scientific writing or whatever, but then when you receive your grades, you realize you got points off for not talking about some aspect about the experiment, but was not listed anywhere in the expectations or the rubric/guidelines.

One strength of this course is that its extremely organized. From day one of the course, each lab session is mapped out so students can plan accordingly for the semester. The instructor, Christine DiMeglio, is a major strength -- she is a gem who genuinely wants everyone to learn and is so sweet and helpful during lab. One weakness is the wide range in TAs - some TAs are very knowledgeable and helpful during lab, while others work more as a chaperone who are just making sure nothing explodes. The structure of Post Lab assignments could be better- they are so sporadic throughout the semester that I dont think they fosters as much learning and growth about scientific writing as they could.

Honestly, I feel like the material of this course lacks breadth. Both my friends at state schools and the grad students I work with expressed surprise at the fact that we don't make Grignards, do Birch reductions (or use a -78 C bath ever), or visualize TLC with anything but UV. It's made me worry somewhat that I'm less prepared than my friends for internships or lab work.
The strengths was the organization. The weakness was the huge difference in grading amongst different TFs.
Great TAs that dont beat around the bush and help to the best of their abilities. No weaknesses.

This course is very well-structured and helps students feel comfortable with organic synthesis and analysis. Dr. DiMeglio does a great job making sure that students are engaged but not too stressed out about the class.
Overall good course, and for a lab class very straight forward and well organized.
less repetitive techniques, sometimes it felt like we were doing similar things over and over again
A very informative and engaging course.

The staff and TAs are wonderful, helpful, approachable people who make the lab (which is mandatory for most things) actually enjoyable. But it is a 4 hour lab which is difficult and not always fun. In terms of improvement, one of the newer labs (I forget which but this was its second year) needed more extensive preparations so that the staff would know how to work out all of the kinks involved in the process.
Overall good. Would be cool to learn different techniques or types of reactions since almost every week is just reflux and then the same 3 evaluations.

I like how this course is very organized and every lab of the semester is already mapped out exactly at the beginning of the year. One weakness is that some of reactions performed in lab had not been covered in the orgo class yet, so we were learning things for the first time (by ourselves), and implementing it in the EPs without knowing if our knowledge of it was correct. Additionally, the CHEM 175 and 221 classes were also learning things at different paces, thus resulting in some students knowing the material while some students were learning it on the spot.

It is an interesting class that is a great complement to applying the lecture material. The downside is that synthesis is long and boring, and gets repetitive towards the end of the semester. In addition, it can be physically tiring to stand up for that long. The lab benches are very uncomfortable to write on.

The course is well organized, with exciting labs every week that make compounds relevant in our everyday lives.  Unlike gen chem lab, the weekly time commitment is quite fair and peaks around the 2 lab reports you will have to write.
The course overall was not bad. The only big thing I would improve is to prepare us a little better for the big post lab assignments because they kind of just pop up, and you have to do them.

The course is very well organized in order to promote student learning. The course materials are detailed and very informative, the curriculum follows a clear structure, feedback is given for all assignments, and the teaching staff are very approachable and involved in the day-to-day labwork.
The strengths of this course are the well-organized course packet, the pre-lab EPs, and the hands on assistance by the TAs.
The grading for the post-lab reports could get annoying sometimes, as the directions were general but the rubrics were specific. Sometimes it felt like the work valued quantity over quality.
At times, the grading seems arbitrary, particularly for EPs.
The labs are very cool: among them we synthesized Tylenol and jasmine oil. The EPs are simple to complete, but quite boring.

This course was very well taught. The lab materials are well organized and coherent. The lab TAs are very prepared for the day's lab and Dr. DiMeglio provides an additional level expertise in the case of technical difficulties. Labs are graded fairly and many labs are interesting, practical, or both. One weakness has to be the lack of organized teaching review sessions for the final exam. While TAs make themselves available for questions, lab check out day could better be utilized as a review day. A couple labs could merge together for a shared review session to prepare people for the final.

Given that semester 1 was about learning the basic concepts and semester 2 was about integrating them in a variety of different syntheses, I can say that I enjoyed semester 2 lab work a lot more. I definitely felt like over time I became much more competent with synthetic techniques. I don't have much to say about how this course could be improved, except for that the post lab assignments are rather harshly graded.
Strengths are the clear lab manual, helpful teaching staff, and overall great environment to do lab work in. There are no weaknesses that I can think of for this class.

Strengths: allowed us to do things that are generally very unique among yale courses. 
Weaknesses: variance in graders in the form of different lab TAs essentially removes the validity of the grade statistics in canvas. Assignments are graded on a rubric which students don't have access to and that doesn't make the criteria very clear at all.
Every ta is different in grading which is annoying

The class is well organized but gets repetitive at times -- we must have done IR at least 10 times. We get how IR works after the second time doing it. Most students, like me, enjoy synthesizing molecules waaayyy more than characterizing them. I don't know if there's a way to do less characterization, given how important of a skill it is to learn, but if so, it would make the class much more enjoyable.

Lots of in class support from the TA and Dr. DiMeglio in terms of troubleshooting experiments and figuring out how to be most efficient in running various protocols. Course was designed such that all "down-time" during reflux can be used to prep further steps or to work on conceptual worksheets, which means that all class time is well spent. Fast turnover rate for EP and PL grading. Wish that EP criteria were more transparent, since I was randomly docked off for random errors during eg. EP5 that were definitely present but not commented upon in the EPs before --- and were not docked for other classmates.

The staff? Amazing. Genuinely helpful, the TA was fantastic. If I had a single question on homework or lab assignments, or even during the actual lab, someone would answer immediately. Very available to help students.
The class is well-organized and the experiments are interesting.

The class is devoted to the students' learning; no work seemed like busy work. The one weakness may be an unstandardized system of grading across the TAs, which makes it difficult to know what exactly is wanted in our work.

Strengths: Course packet lays out everything very well. 
Weaknesses: TAs may be different on their grading which is unfair to students.

Strength: smoothly ran
Weaknesses: time commitment (but that is inevitable)
The course as structures to allow for each individual to proceed at their own pace.
I enjoyed taking this course, and I felt like the course packet was well organized and really helped me.

Strengths: very caring instructor (Dr. DiMeglio), TAs and instructor are always there in lab to explain what's going on, answer any questions, and help with setup; Weaknesses: grades and rigor of course can be very TA dependent, though the slight curve at the end does aim to adjust for this

Weaknessesall the labs blend together. We do synthesis labs every week and it definitely gets boring after the first few

StrengthsDr. DiMeglio is one of my favorite people at Yale. She is so kind, so smart, so helpful, so engaged, I could go on. She is always available to help and to chat.
I also did learn a LOT of lab skills and chem concepts through lab.
I really enjoyed synthesizing compounds that are prevalent in daily life, such as acetaminophen. More experiments like that I feel like would engage the class more.

The strength of the course is that it is often directly relevant to lecture material, and the importance of each mechanism is emphasized so that the actions we perform in lab don't feel pointless. The teaching staff is reliable and available to answer any and all questions. The weaknesses were in the secondary assignments. Many of the "Response" assignments felt like needlessly pedantic busy work, while the Post Lab A was stressful in that it was worth a significant portion of the grade while not being related to much of what was emphasized in class. I think assignments that are more closely related to the material we are responsible for would be most useful - which is especially important when the grading is extremely picky and hair-splitting, as it often is.

The weakness of this course was that the labs at one point started to feel repetitive. We were using the same techniques to synthesize different products, especially since we already learned most of the techniques in the first semester.
Coming out of this course I felt a lot more comfortable working in a lab setting. However, the assignments ocassionally felt arbitrary with abstract learning goals.
Great course

Pls and eps were graded too harshly, unfir and unessesary points taken off for petty formatting things
Wish the eps were more intellectually useful rather than busy work
Liked using chem draw didnt like the chemistry data base to search for articles

Strengths: Great professor and teaching assistants, organized course packet, helpful feedback

Weaknesses: not as much practice with NMR, which students may benefit from for the final
The class was able to be engaging without being impossibly difficult. The reactions we learned usually supplemented the material that we were leaning in the lecture class.
It is well taught and the faculty is friendly.
Very well organized and engaging. The course is set up to help you learn and engage you in the material.

We did a lot of different labs, which was good, and we did the same techniques several times to bang them into our heads. However, it was a lot of working from wrote and just following a cookbook which could get tedious.

All of the teaching staff were very helpful, friendly, and knowledgeable, which made the class very enjoyable. Some of the experiments were tested out on early lab days, which could get frustrating for those in Monday lab, but nonetheless, the class was very well run.

Weaknesses: answering questions for the EP and writing the lab report are sometimes graded based on buzz words. While this is a insignificant part of the grade, you will lose points despite getting the point across. Additionally, the class is a full credit worth of work.
Strengths: DiMeglio is a great instructor and the class teaches important skills.

This class is great. If anything I think clearer rubrics/instructions for the post lab assignments would be very beneficial because a lot of points get taken off for very specific things that no one knows about.

weaknesses - grading that seems almost petty; I was docked many points for small reasons, and there is no budging or convincing the TA to look at your grade. I thought that was unfair, and the points docked were not for things that were wrong with my chemistry knowledge, they were for sentence structure....in a chemistry laboratory course, when my writing was readable (I checked, and had someone else check it over after I received my grade and was surprised). I am very interested in laboratory skills in chemistry, but this course made me wary of taking future lab courses, instead I might just opt out using research.
The TAs are a strength, however much of your grade in the class rests on two lab reports and the final. They should make the point distribution more spread out along the labs themselves.
This course is very well organized, and Dr. DiMeglio takes a real effort to get to know all of her students. The only weakness is discrepancies between TAs and how they grade EPs.

the organic lab is a lot better than the gen Chem lab -- really well organised and, there aren't many tasks that feel like they're just filling up time. Everything seems like it has a purpose and is useful for learning. The in thing that could be improved is the lab reports -- they need clearer guidelines on what is expected, what needs to be included etc. (the Scientific writing guide often gives different instructions to what is expected by the TAs who are grading the report).
No real weaknesses. Strength was that the labs were engaging. Maybe more TFs so each had a smaller group.
Poor curving and grading was very tough.
I thought that this course did a great job reinforcing information from class, augmenting in-class information with additional topics, and facilitated a better understanding of lab techniques.

I wish we did an NMR experiment/used an NMR machine to print an NMR, which we could then use for product identification (similar to IR). NMR seemed kinda pointless because we never actually did anything with it. It was useful for lecture though.
Grading was very strict and made for a lot of stress. Well organized and lots of support from TAs and professor.

time in lab is pretty good. grading of PLs and comparable assignments is highly formulaic and many points are allocated to very minor formatting styles. It would be good to have the rubric ahead of time, or some other way of guiding the writing of PLs.
The course packet was helpful. It could have been more consistent with grading.
Strengths: very well-organized, expectations clearly laid out, experiments are fun and exciting, helpful compliment to orgo lecture

This course was overall well taught by both Dr. DiMeglio and the TA's. My only suggestion would be to provide a rubric as to some of the things that cause points to be taken off when submitting assignments like the PLAs.

The strength of this course was the quality of the facilities we had to do the experiments in. The weaknesses meanwhile were multifold. The course packet is a mess and constantly mixes formats and types of information presented. There is a big emphasis in our own work on having a professional sheen but that is lacking in the course packet with various misspellings and typos. Additionally, for the post labs, the information on formatting is spread out confusingly over multiple documents on canvas and the examples of how each section are supposed to look actually don't match the instructions. This leads to great confusion over what good "scientific writing" actually looks like. Another weakness of the course is that what we get graded on is actually pretty irrelevant to the point of the lab course. The final multiple choice test is a hodgepodge of material that is sort of covered in the course packet but has nothing to do with our actual lab abilities. In the future, I would recommend having a lab practical as the final.

The course was very helpful in covering some of the reactions learned in the corresponding lecture class. The Experimental Plan assignments were also very useful for learning how to organize a safety data sheet for chemicals included in each experiment as well as how to plan procedures.
Not to have major assignments and post lab reports and final exams during the same week as midterm exams in Orgo 2 lecture class

A great introductory course to an organic chemistry lab setting; however, even with the once-per-week class schedule, the workload is on par with or exceeding that of classes that are a full credit. No complaints about the workload, but I feel that students get the short end of the stick in only receiving 0.5 credits for taking this course.

Strengths of this course include a well written course packet, a clearly structured syllabus and lab schedule, as well as abundant resources, such as the TAs and Dr. DiMeglio.

There weren't very many weaknesses, except for the grading of assignments. Points were often taken off for forgetting to put a measurement or a specific phrase, rather than for lack of comprehension.
This course is taught very well. The TA's are very responsive to questions and Dr. D is always around for additional knowledge! The course packet and modules are very organized.
Grades should be distributed differently. We should not have points taken off because of our English or structure of the assignments.
Prof. DiMeglio is extremely nice and the labs are always very doable in the time aloted.

Dr. Dimeglio is fabulous! The syllabus is so well-designed, the course packet is easy to read and informative, and the labs are fun and practically useful - I've not only learned but also internalized a lot of the lab practices and methods that we covered. The lab reports are also very fair, though I think the questions asked could be a little bit more aligned with the content of the course. I also think that there is a consistent issue with grading discrepancies across TAs for different sections... I do think that the lab experience in chemistry courses is highly related to the quality/attitude of the TA for each student's section.
If they had an interest in chemistry, or otherwise needed a chem lab I would recommend it.
Definitely. The professor is awesome and you become really close with the other students in your lab group.

No.  The atmosphere is significantly better than gen chem, so you have that to look forward to if you're required to take this course, but if you're not required, get out.  I don't think I learned anything useful all semester and it is just a constant stress.
Yeah, I liked this lab, it was fun.

Yes! Orgo II Lab is a really nice lab to balance out your other coursework. The workload is not much compared to other classes, so each week is not stressful. But you should just make sure to know the reactions in general so that later it is not difficult to learn them all for the final exam.

I would recommend this course! Although it was a challenging course, I learned a lot of valuable skills and got more experience in a laboratory setting, which I am sure will prove to be useful in my future.

Yes, I would recommend this course to another student because I had no experience in a lab before this class, and after taking two semesters of organic chemistry lab I have learned a lot of common techniques and methods for synthesis and analysis of products.

O-chem lab was pretty fun. Since % yield wasn't graded, it's okay to mess up as long as you understand why things didn't work. Pretty interesting to see that the reactions you learn in lecture actually work and make products that you want to make.

Im sure if youre taking this its because you have to but no this class sucks. Its just nonstop busy-work for only half a credit and you get points off on assignments for the stupidest things. After about 40 hours spent on EPs all semester, your final grade comes down to your PLA, PLB, and final exam grade. Nothing else matters because everyone gets about the same grades on everything else. How you do on the Post-Labs is just anyones guess. Youll get points off for the most random things that you never could have anticipated. But if you do well on PLA and PLB and dont mess up on the final you should be fine.
I would recommend this course for people who wish to learn laboratory skills relating to organic chemistry.
Yes! It is fun and related to the lecture.
If you have to take it, you will.

probably a good idea to take the lab if you are taking the lecture class, because it somewhat helped to understand material. but, if you are taking orgo lab, you are probably doing it for some type of requirement, so you have to take it

This course is really only for people who need it.  I would not recommend taking the lab if you don't like chemistry because organic chemistry is extremely hard.  Although the lab itself is not that bad, the underlying concepts are hard to grasp and the final will be super hard.
I would recommend this class for anyone who is required to take it, but would not recommend this class as an elective.
NO
Take it if you need to.
Yes, good way to understand the concepts in organic chem
Only if you need it for credit.
I would only if they needed it for their requirement.

I mean I guess. This class is one of those classes that most people have to take anyways, and yes it is boring to keep doing the same things over and over again like reflux, recrystallization, vacuum filtration, but it's not too bad.
Only if it is a pre-req for your stem major or pre-med.  Much easier sci distributional requirment credits can be found elsewhere.
I would recommend if it is a prerequisite.
Yes I would.
Definitely. Professor DiMeglio is very nice and understanding of students situations. The TAs are also very dedicated.
Yes, I would. Orgo lab is a great class.
Yes. It's actually interesting to see how Orgo and lab interact, at least for this semester.
Yes, if you need to take organic chemistry lab
Yes, its an interesting course.
Obviously take the lab if you have to, but unless you really enjoy laboratory work, those 4 hours could be spent in a better way.

It's fine to take as a requirement. Isn't awful like gen chem. But really no reason to take it if you don't need to. Grading is arbitrary and points are taken off for the randomest small details since otherwise everyone would get an A. Your experience varies hugely on your TA.
Yes, I would absolutely recommend this course! It's super chill, even more so than the first semester, and it was a very enjoyable experience overall.

I would recommend this course, especially if you need it (as a prerequisite). After first semester of orgo lab, you start to get the hang of how the class goes and orgo 2 lab will be much more enjoyable.
Yes, its a good class.

Second semester orgo lab is even better than the first. There is something so gratifying about making real compounds  the fact that I made ibuprofen is unreal. Plus, the crystals are pretty. Compared to first semester when everything was brand new, the lab starts to get a little monotonous as the same techniques are used again and again, but that means you also get very good at TLC and IR etc.
Sure, the reactions are pretty cool. It is made better by those around you and a cool TA.

Yes, I would recommend this course to any student taking the organic chemistry lecture. It is rewarding and interesting to see the principles learned in lecture carried out in real labwork, and each course enriches understanding of the other.

Yes. The format of this lab is perfect. There are no weekly lab reports, but rather 2 major post-lab assignments throughout the course. The labs are interesting and reinforce what we learn in lecture.

I would highly recommend this course. Although most people will end up taking it as part of a prerequisite or because they are taking the organic chemistry complement, this course is still very enjoyable and, I might add, possible to have fun taking it. The relative challenge of each lab becomes easier with time while the experiment becoming more interesting as the course progresses. The synthesis of practical and valuable compounds like acetaminophen made me realize that this course provides a very valuable skill set.
I would recommend CHEM 223L to other students. It was one of the better lab courses I have taken as a premed.
Absolutely, great class for learning how to practically use organic chemistry.
Yes, if you're alright with frustratingly small mistakes and being graded on a somewhat unclear rubric. The material and class is fascinating, the grading is a bit rough.
Chances are you need to take this course. It's pretty fun, so it won't be that bad.
If you're taking this course you probably need it for pre-med or some life science major --- but it's definitely an enjoyable experience because the course builds on past knowledge.
I would recommend this course for sure.
Chances are if you're taking this class you have to take it. So yeah
Yes, it was fun! Better than O-Chem 1 in my opinion because you get to actually use all of the techniques to synthesize compounds.
only if you have to

Given that this course is usually taken out of necessity...
If you plan to take this course, make sure to finish the EPs with an extra day and the PLs with several extra days in case you have any questions. Dr. DiMeglio is always open to questions and gives great feedback. Read through the requirements carefully for the PLs, EPs, and notebook pages because students tend to miss silly points on things they have control over.
Probably a requirement, but it is a great upgrade from Gen Chem lab.
I would recommend this course to any student wishing to pursue a career in the sciences.
I would definitely recommend this course to anyone taking organic chemistry because it reinforces the concepts well and puts meaning to the learning from the textbook.
YES! very fun lab course, and exciting to see applications of organic chemistry theory in practical lab reactions

I would. For a lab, its greatnot a ton of out of class time on a weekly basis, really just the 2 big lab reports suck. The final also is NOT bad at all.  Dr. D is amazing. Definitely the best lab Ive taken.
Yes! If you like lab work youll find synthesizing a new compound every week exciting.
It is definitely better to take this lab than the general chemistry one.

Most people who take the course are required to, but it is generally not too stressful unless your TA is a really picky grader. Many people say it's even easier than Orgo I lab, and I did not find that to be the case - not because of content, but mostly because the expectations of putting forth perfect work are much higher so the grading can be extremely frustrating. The in-lab experience is fairly relaxed - you get to work at your own pace and there are lots of people around to help you. Outside of lab, week-to-week it is usually just the EP assignments which are the same from the first semester. Starting the post-lab assignments early is a good way to mitigate last-minute stress.
Most people are taking this because it is a requirement. But otherwise, I'm not sure if I would recommend if you have already taken Orgo Lab I. I didn't feel like I learned many new things.
Ya
I would recommend this to any student taking the second semester of organic chemistry; the lab course reinforces concepts from the lecture course
Yes, taking this class allows you to understand many of the reactions that have allowed for life as we know it.
Yes. It is a good lab course that requires effort, but its not too challenging.
I would recommend the lab. A student is likely only taking it as a requirement, but it is enjoyable and you will practice your lab skills.
Yeah I guess. You're not taking this unless you have to, and it's not the worst thing in the world, so just do it.
Yes! Once you've taken orgo lab 1, definitely stay for the second semester. You really get to expand on your skills and feel much more comfortable.
Yes, if the student is planning on a future in chemistry this class is a must (other than the fact that its required). It nicely compliments the class by putting the lectures into practice.

Yes! This class is really fun and chill and DiMeglio is such a sweetheart. You do learn a lot in this class and do really cool fun experiments, but honestly the TAs are super nice and everyone taking it is in it together.
you have to take it, so take it
Youre probably only taking this as a requirement, but its very doable and enjoyable.
Yes, great for learning more techniques and laboratory skills.
I would! Helped solidify the concepts taught in Organic Lecture.
Yes I would. You learn a lot of valuable lab skills.
If you need the lab credit/lab skills, yes.
Only if needed for your major.
Only if necessary.
I would recommend this course to any student wanting to apply what they learn in organic chemistry lecture to a lab environment.
Yes

Yes, not a bad lab by any means. Sometimes it feels super long (it is 4 hours after all), but you'll get through it. The workload is probably the most fair out of all my classes (2 major lab reports, one weekly assignment) and it is very manageable. This structure really worked, so if they keep it the course will be great.
Not unless you need to take it for major or premed since you need to be very thorough in preparing each assignment to ensure you do not miss points. Work can be time-consuming for this reason.
if you're taking it, it's because you have to.
Yes if you like lab
Yes, great way to reinforce concepts learned in lecture and great way to develop laboratory skills. Lots of support from TAs and Dr. DiMeglio facilitate understanding and student engagement.
I would recommend this course to students who have already taken 222L and want to further improve and apply the skills learned there, through a greater amount of experimentation.
This course is wonderful because the course packet was clear and expectations were well stated. I would recommend this course as a very good lab course.
It is a good course, but I would only do it if you love chemistry lab or for a major.
Yes
This isn't the sort of course that you take by choice.

Yes, it's required for most med schools and most of the biology and chemistry related majors I believe. It is also an engaging and fun course to take, with practical application of concepts learned in lecture.
I would recommend the course! You learn a lot!
Yes, it teaches you very good lab skills.
Yes
Yes! If you are at all interested in chemical lab work - professionally, academically, or for fun - take this class. So well-structured, very much worth the time spent in lab, and deeply engaging!
